Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Perovskite solar photovoltaics and continuous flash sublimation manufacturing
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of solar devices based on metal-halide perovskite semiconductors. For perovskite solar modules, applications include transport (e.g., drones), indoor devices (e.g., sensors), or high-altitude and space applications where silicon devices are too expensive, heavy, or not efficient enough. Recent estimates indicate the market for indoor photovoltarics could reach $1B annually by 2024. Silicon is not cost competitive today ($50-100/m2) and cannot reach 30% efficiency indoors, a requirement for commercial success. Satellite and high-altitude drone applications are nascent and rapidly growing. Thin film perovskite photovoltaics have a natural advantage over crystalline silicon photovoltaics in drone technologies. Perovskite solar cells have demonstrated high power-per-weight performance (23 kW/kg), a key metric for these applications. Continuous flash sublimation is highly tunable and controllable, enabling the materials to be optimized to enable manufacturing methods.<br/><br/>This I-Corps project is based on the development of a new manufacturing method – continuous flash sublimation (CFS) – for the mass-scale production of perovskite-based optoelectronic devices. Translating conventional lab-scale perovskite solution-processing methods to large-scale manufacturing is challenging due to the use of solvents. CFS is a vapor-based process that does not use solvents. In addition, CFS is safe, fast, simple, inexpensive, and scalable, which will allow it to be readily incorporated into existing high-throughput commercial manufacturing lines. CFS manufacturing may significantly lower the integration barrier associated with the production of perovskite semiconductors for solar power production, as well as for solid state lighting, display technology, and X-ray detection for medical sensors.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Perovskites are an exciting class of materials because of how they interact with light. Applications could be better solar panels, better light bulbs, or better medical imaging tools.

BlueDot Photonics wants to commercialize a perovskite material with a unique property. It can split a high-energy beam of light into twice as much lower-energy light. In our I-Corps project, we spoke with over 150 people to find possible applications for the new material. We spoke with people in the solar, medical imaging, x-ray detection, nuclear medicine, and lighting and display industries.

Our first focus was on solar panels for low-earth orbit satellites. There is growing interest in using such satellites for imaging and satellite internet. Satellite manufacturers rely on expensive solar cells that cost over $100/watt to power the satellites today. This works for single satellites with a defined mission. It is too expensive for thousands of satellites. Unfortunately, the market is small (total addressable market of <$50M per year). And it is challenging to enter (i.e., long qualification cycles). Given this, we pivoted, looking for a higher value opportunity.

We shifted focus to medical imaging tools. Medical imaging tools often use X-rays and other high-energy radiation. Perovskites have unique properties that could make them good at detecting x-rays and other radiation. We spoke with medical professionals who run the imaging tools and the tool manufacturers who make them. We heard two complementary needs. Medical professionals want to reduce the dose of radiation they expose a patient to. The tool manufacturers want to find a way to lower the cost of their tools while keeping the current level of performance.

We had found a market with two clear needs. We now need to conduct feasibility studies to confirm our technology is a good fit. The risks would be high. And the process to gain medical use approval is long and expensive. Again, we decided the barriers to this market would be too much.

We went back to one of our first hypotheses. Our technology could make solar panels better. So, we engaged solar panel manufacturers who make rooftop and solar farm panels. Our focus was on finding the best way to package our technology. And how to think about pricing. We discovered that solar panel manufacturers are desperate for low cost and easy to adopt technology to improve panel efficiency. Solar panel efficiency increases by less than half a percent per year on average. There is fierce competition as well. Any amount of positive performance can be a differentiator. But they do not want to disrupt their current production processes. They adopt technology fastest when it is drop-in ready. We spoke with solar panel manufacturers, solar panel installers, solar developers, solar panel component suppliers, independent engineers, and project financiers.

At the end of our customer discovery journey, we decided that the best path for commercializing the new material was in the silicon solar panel industry. BlueDot Photonics has since spun out of the University of Washington, hired 5 full-time employees, earned $1.5M in grants and awards, and raised over $1.4M of private financing for commercialization efforts.
